title: Worked Solution
text:
All of the choices can be used to support the statement that ancient people thought disease was transmitted by things they could not see.

Historical attempts to contain disease, like quarantining, demonstrate that ancient people believed diseases could be spread between individuals without any visible means of transmission.

Hygiene practices by the ancient Greeks, such as the use of herbal remedies and fumigation, were based on the belief that disease was caused by invisible entities.

The creation of sanitation infrastructure in Rome, such as public baths and aqueducts, was based on the belief that stagnant water and poor hygiene were a breeding ground for diseases caused by things that could not be seen.

Overall, these examples demonstrate that ancient people believed in the transmission of disease by things they could not see, and acted accordingly to prevent or control outbreaks.
